Adam James Finley

PhD Student at the University of Exeter. Supervised by Prof. Sean Matt.

Contact Info

Welcome! This site contains information and materials related to the PhD project of Adam Finley at the University of Exeter (2016-2020).

I aim to understand the interaction of dynamo-driven magnetic fields on stellar winds from low-mass stars. These magnetised winds remove angular momentum from their host stars, causing them to spin-down with age.

Get Started!

Research Interests

Stellar Winds

Low-mass stars host hot, million degree, atmospheres which drive a steady stream of plasma from their surface. These winds carry away mass, but also angular momentum which is crucial in explaining the observed rotation periods of stars as they age.

Stellar Magnetism

Low-mass stars generate magnetic fields through an internal dynamo; powered by the interplay of rotation and convection. These magnetic fields energise the outer atmosphere, influence the mass-loss in the stellar wind, and the subsequent angular momentum-loss process.

Numerical Simulation

In order to study the influence of magnetic fields have on angular momentum loss in stellar winds, I perform magnetohydrodynamic simulations using the PLUTO code.

Rotation Evolution

I produce semi-analytic relationships for the braking torque on stars, given their observable properties. These formulae can then be used to model the rotation period evolution of low-mass stars, or in comparison to the torques required by current rotation-evolution models.

Published Papers

The Effect of Combined Magnetic Geometries on Thermally Driven Winds I: Interaction of Dipolar and Quadrupolar Fields Finley, Adam J., and Sean P. Matt. The Astrophysical Journal 845.1 (2017): 46.

The Effect of Combined Magnetic Geometries on Thermally Driven Winds. II. Dipolar, Quadrupolar, and Octupolar Topologies Finley, Adam J., and Sean P. Matt. The Astrophysical Journal 854.2 (2018): 78.

The Effect of Magnetic Variability on Stellar Angular Momentum Loss I: The Solar Wind Torque During Sunspot Cycles 23 & 24 Finley, Adam J., Sean P. Matt, and Victor See. The Astrophysical Journal 864.2 (2018): 125.
